Situation1: A minor misunderstanding about weekend plans just arose.
Expectation2: Organize and participate in peaceful protests to raise awareness about social issues.
Situation2: A fellow activist is live-streaming from a small demonstration right now and has asked for more people to show up if they are free.
Story: I stare at my phone, torn. My boyfriend’s last message is curt—he’s upset that I forgot our brunch plans for Saturday. He wants to talk now, to clear the air before it festers. I know how important it is to him that we resolve things quickly, that I don’t just brush off his feelings. But as I type out an apology, another notification pops up: a fellow activist is live-streaming from the city square. The turnout is small, and she’s asking for backup. I promised the group I’d be there whenever I could, especially when numbers are low. My heart pounds as I picture her standing there, holding a sign, hoping for support. I want to be the reliable partner who listens and fixes things, but I also want to be the committed activist who shows up when it matters. My fingers hover over the keyboard, caught between two conversations, two worlds, and I can feel the weight of both expectations pressing in on me.
